segment.source: This article explains how to add dragging and dropping in your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: This article explains how to add dragging and dropping in your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: Drag and drop
segment.target: Drag and drop

segment.source: Drag and drop
segment.target: Drag and drop

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This article explains how to add dragging and dropping in your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: This article explains how to add dragging and dropping in your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: Drag and drop is a classic, natural way of interacting with content such as images and files.
segment.target: Drag and drop is a classic, natural way of interacting with content such as images and files.

segment.source: Once implemented, drag and drop works seamlessly in all directions, including app-to-app, app-to-desktop, and desktop-to app.
segment.target: Once implemented, drag and drop works seamlessly in all directions, including app-to-app, app-to-desktop, and desktop-to app.

segment.source: Set valid areas
segment.target: Set valid areas

segment.source: Use the AllowDropAllowDrop and CanDragCanDrag properties to designate the areas of your app valid for dragging and dropping.
segment.target: Use the AllowDropAllowDrop and CanDragCanDrag properties to designate the areas of your app valid for dragging and dropping.

segment.source: The markup below shows how to set a specific area of the app as a valid for dropping using the AllowDropAllowDrop in XAML.
segment.target: The markup below shows how to set a specific area of the app as a valid for dropping using the AllowDropAllowDrop in XAML.

segment.source: If a user tries to drop somewhere else, the system won't let them.
segment.target: If a user tries to drop somewhere else, the system won't let them.

segment.source: If you want users to be able to drop items anywhere on your app, set the entire background as a drop target.
segment.target: If you want users to be able to drop items anywhere on your app, set the entire background as a drop target.

segment.source: Main
segment.target: Main

segment.source: With dragging, you'll usually want to be specific about what's draggable.
segment.target: With dragging, you'll usually want to be specific about what's draggable.

segment.source: Users will want to drag certain items, like pictures, not everything in your app.
segment.target: Users will want to drag certain items, like pictures, not everything in your app.

segment.source: Here's how to set CanDragCanDrag using XAML.
segment.target: Here's how to set CanDragCanDrag using XAML.

segment.source: Main
segment.target: Main

segment.source: You don't need to do any other work to allow dragging, unless you want to customize the UI (which is covered later in this article).
segment.target: You don't need to do any other work to allow dragging, unless you want to customize the UI (which is covered later in this article).

segment.source: Dropping requires a few more steps.
segment.target: Dropping requires a few more steps.

segment.source: Handle the DragOver event
segment.target: Handle the DragOver event

segment.source: The DragOverDragOver event fires when a user has dragged an item over your app, but not yet dropped it.
segment.target: The DragOverDragOver event fires when a user has dragged an item over your app, but not yet dropped it.

segment.source: In this handler, you need to specify what kind of operations your app supports using the DragEventArgs.AcceptedOperationAcceptedOperation property.
segment.target: In this handler, you need to specify what kind of operations your app supports using the DragEventArgs.AcceptedOperationAcceptedOperation property.

segment.source: Copy is the most common.
segment.target: Copy is the most common.

segment.source: Main
segment.target: Main

segment.source: Process the Drop event
segment.target: Process the Drop event

segment.source: The DropDrop event occurs when the user releases items in a valid drop area.
segment.target: The DropDrop event occurs when the user releases items in a valid drop area.

segment.source: Process them using the DragEventArgs.DataViewDataView property.
segment.target: Process them using the DragEventArgs.DataViewDataView property.

segment.source: For simplicity in the example below, we'll assume the user dropped a single photo and access.
segment.target: For simplicity in the example below, we'll assume the user dropped a single photo and access.

segment.source: In reality, users can drop multiple items of varying formats simultaneously.
segment.target: In reality, users can drop multiple items of varying formats simultaneously.

segment.source: Your app should handle this possibility by checking what types of files were dropped and processing them accordingly, and notifying the user if they're trying to do something your app don't support.
segment.target: Your app should handle this possibility by checking what types of files were dropped and processing them accordingly, and notifying the user if they're trying to do something your app don't support.

segment.source: Main
segment.target: Main

segment.source: Customize the UI
segment.target: Customize the UI

segment.source: The system provides a default UI for dragging and dropping.
segment.target: The system provides a default UI for dragging and dropping.

segment.source: However, you can also choose to customize various parts of the UI by setting custom captions and glyphs, or by opting not to show a UI at all.
segment.target: However, you can also choose to customize various parts of the UI by setting custom captions and glyphs, or by opting not to show a UI at all.

segment.source: To customize the UI, use the DragUIOverrideDragUiOverride property in the DragOverDragOver event handler.
segment.target: To customize the UI, use the DragUIOverrideDragUiOverride property in the DragOverDragOver event handler.

segment.target: Main
